articles.headline: Senate Votes Down Broad Obamacare Repeal
articles.snippet: The fact that the plan came up well short of even 50 votes was an ominous sign for Republican leaders still grappling with a formula to pass final health care legislation later this week.
articles.abstract: The fact that the plan came up well short of even 50 votes was an ominous sign for Republican leaders still grappling with a formula to pass final health care legislation later this week.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate voted narrowly on Tuesday to begin debate on a bill to repeal major provisions of the Affordable Care Act, but hours later, Republican leaders suffered a setback when their most comprehensive plan to replace President Barack Obama’s health law fell far short of the votes it needed.
articles.byline: By Thomas Kaplan and Robert Pear

articles.headline: McCain Returns to Cast Vote to Help the President Who Derided Him
articles.snippet: Senator John McCain ambled into the Senate chamber less than two weeks after brain surgery to help put a health care bill over the line.
articles.abstract: Senator John McCain ambled into the Senate chamber less than two weeks after brain surgery to help put a health care bill over the line.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator John McCain is less the lion of the Senate than its wildcat, veering through the decades from war hero to Republican presidential nominee to irascible foil for an unlikely president.

articles.headline: As Emissions Scandal Widens, Diesel’s Future Looks Shaky in Europe
articles.snippet: Diesel, once a cornerstone of German engineering, is facing a growing backlash among consumers, regulators and cities.
articles.abstract: Diesel, once a cornerstone of German engineering, is facing a growing backlash among consumers, regulators and cities.
articles.lead_paragraph: WOLFSBURG, Germany — The latest victims of noxious diesel fumes may be the fuel technology itself.

articles.headline: Some Bitcoin Backers Are Defecting to Create a Rival Currency
articles.snippet: Bitcoin Cash, to be available Aug. 1, sprang from a feud over how to govern a decentralized, open-source technology with no one set of leaders or owners.
articles.abstract: Bitcoin Cash, to be available Aug. 1, sprang from a feud over how to govern a decentralized, open-source technology with no one set of leaders or owners.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For the last two years, rival factions have been vying for control of the Bitcoin virtual currency and its global network of computers and supporters.

articles.headline: Trump Finds Reason for the U.S. to Remain in Afghanistan: Minerals
articles.snippet: Last week, as the White House fell into an increasingly fractious debate over Afghanistan policy, Trump aides met with a chemical executive to discuss the potential for extracting rare-earth minerals.
articles.abstract: Last week, as the White House fell into an increasingly fractious debate over Afghanistan policy, Trump aides met with a chemical executive to discuss the potential for extracting rare-earth minerals.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump, searching for a reason to keep the United States in Afghanistan after 16 years of war, has latched on to a prospect that tantalized previous administrations: Afghanistan’s vast mineral wealth, which his advisers and Afghan officials have told him could be profitably extracted by Western companies.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and James Risen

articles.headline: Seesawing Fate of Legendary Reflects the Film Industry’s Volatility
articles.snippet: Once a Hollywood darling, a boutique studio has endured box office flops, and is dealing with the financial problems of its Chinese owner.
articles.abstract: Once a Hollywood darling, a boutique studio has endured box office flops, and is dealing with the financial problems of its Chinese owner.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Two summers ago, Legendary Entertainment was the belle of the Hollywood ball.

articles.headline: At a Moment of Success, U.S.C. Is Rocked by Scandal
articles.snippet: Did the university move too slowly in responding to allegations of drug abuse by one of its most prominent deans?
articles.abstract: Did the university move too slowly in responding to allegations of drug abuse by one of its most prominent deans?
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — When the University of Southern California lured a world-class ophthalmologist to run its medical school 10 years ago, it was part of a long, concerted effort to transform U.S.C.’s image from a school primarily for the children of this city’s wealthy, mostly white, elite with a penchant for partying and football into a major academic research institution.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Jennifer Medina

articles.headline: ‘Minecraft: The Island’ Blurs the Line Between Fiction and Gaming
articles.snippet: Max Brooks’s new novel has an unusual feature: It can also be played within a video game.
articles.abstract: Max Brooks’s new novel has an unusual feature: It can also be played within a video game.
articles.lead_paragraph: The protagonist of Max Brooks’s new fantasy novel doesn’t have a name, a gender or even normal human appendages. Instead of hands, the narrator has clumsy, flesh-toned cubes, just one more weird feature of the strange and unsettling world where the story unfolds, where everything — the sun, clouds, cows, mushrooms, watermelons — is composed of squares.

articles.headline: How Microsoft Has Become the Surprise Innovator in PCs
articles.snippet: For years, Apple was the innovative leader in personal computers. Not anymore.
articles.abstract: For years, Apple was the innovative leader in personal computers. Not anymore.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Microsoft unveiled the first Surface tablet five years ago, it was a spectacular failure.

articles.headline: Trump Says Transgender People Will Not Be Allowed in the Military
articles.snippet: The president’s announcement, made on Twitter, blindsided the Pentagon and Republican congressional leaders and thrilled members of his conservative base.
articles.abstract: The president’s announcement, made on Twitter, blindsided the Pentagon and Republican congressional leaders and thrilled members of his conservative base.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump abruptly announced a ban on transgender people serving in the military on Wednesday, blindsiding his defense secretary and Republican congressional leaders with a snap decision that reversed a year-old policy reviled by social conservatives.
articles.byline: By Julie Hirschfeld Davis and Helene Cooper
